source.query: seated squat hold isometric muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Seated Sandbag Squat Hold is a challenging isometric exercise primarily targeting the glutes, quads, hamstrings, and deep core stabilizers (abs, obliques), forcing them to work hard to maintain the squat position and handle the shifting weight, improving functional strength, balance, and posture through a controlled, multi-planar squatting pattern with high demands on core tension and spinal stability. [1, 2, 3]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Legs): Quadriceps (front of thighs), Glutes (buttocks), Hamstrings (back of thighs). 
• Core/Stabilizers: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis, Erector Spinae (lower back) - essential for maintaining an upright torso and controlling the unstable load. 
• Upper Body (Stabilization): Lats, traps, and shoulder girdle muscles, especially when holding the bag in a front-rack or Zercher position. 
• Grip: Forearms and hands, due to the unstable nature of the sandbag. [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Movement Pattern 

• Type: Isometric (static hold), isometric squat variation, functional strength, stability training. 
• Action: Bending at the hips and knees to lower into a squat, then holding that position, engaging the core and glutes to prevent the torso from collapsing forward. 
• Key Cues: 

    • Grab the ground: Imagine your feet gripping the floor to activate lower body chains. 
    • Chest tall: Maintain an upright torso to keep tension and engage the core. 
    • Squeeze the bag: Keep tension on the sandbag by pulling handles apart (if applicable) to engage lats and core. 
    • Controlled Breathing: Inhale to brace, hold tension, then exhale as you return to standing (if doing reps) or maintain steady breaths in the hold. 

• Benefits: Develops strength in dynamic stability, improves posture, and trains the body to work as an integrated unit. [1, 2, 3, 7, 10, 11, 12]
